          Sin City, directed by Frank Miller, is a film based on the Sin City graphic novels. The movie was unique in a stylistic sense; however, I would not watch it again. To be transparent, I found the film so painfully dull and confusing that I could not make it to the end. Although the detailing within this movie proved to be interesting, the overall film was a bit hard to navigate. If you were to look away from your screen for more than one second, it felt like you missed an entire storyline. However, there is always good within the bad, so one exciting factor I pulled from this film was that it presented itself as a comic book through an actual movie setting. I have never seen this in a movie, so this was the only detail to capture my attention. Although my opinion stands, a few criteria stood out throughout reviewing this film: creativity, characters, and pacing.
           One fascinating aspect of this movie is the overall creativity. When the film opens, we see a woman standing on a balcony. A man comes outside to conversate with her. The woman plays a character known as "The Customer," and the man plays a character known as "The Man." The Customer plays a significant part because not only is she the first character introduced, but through her character, we see the first appearance of color; her red dress. Considering that the film is in black and white, I found the color appearances remarkably interesting throughout the movie because color only appears through introducing a significant person or object. Anytime we see color, that object either gets damaged, the character dies, or becomes brutally wounded. Frank Miller honestly had an eye for creativity through producing this film.
           The following form of criteria that I took notice of was the overall characters and their meaning. For example, John Hartigan appears in the first scene. To my understanding, John is a detective and one of the main protagonists in Sin City. John is an interesting character because he presents himself as more of a mysterious type. However, when an exciting character appears, they become killed off shortly after, or we never see them again. To my knowledge, Frank Miller implemented this detail to draw more attention to each character and recapture the audience's lost attention. Through this challenging detail and the literal film, we cannot come to a deep understanding of the characters or their life stories.
           Finally, the last section of criteria that I noticed was the overall pacing of this film. This aspect ruined both the movie and the overall experience. From the beginning, if you did not listen closely or purposefully look for minor details, you would be completely lost once the central part of the scene occurred. For example, Goldie appears during the film's middle portion. Although her character's storyline ends shortly after being introduced, the storyline shift will quickly confuse you if you do not give your undivided attention to that scene. After Goldie dies, Her twin sister appears to torment a man named Marv; this detail completely lost my attention because, for the longest time, I could not tell if Goldie was still alive or if it was her ghost. It was never clear that she was her twin until the scene ended. I also believe that the movie did not have a set plotline. Throughout watching it, the characters switched out so often that it was challenging to keep up with who we were following and what plot to follow. Once one character appeared, it seemed you had only minutes to follow that storyline until another appeared. This cycle repeats itself multiple times throughout the movie, making it exceedingly difficult to finish.
           Sin City is a film representing the Sin City graphic novels authored by Frank Miller. At first glance, the film looks quite interesting; the cover art makes you want to click on it straight away, leading the audience to believe that they are sitting down to watch an action-packed, exciting crime movie. In all honesty, my first assumption led me to believe that Sin City was a film almost like the television show Law and Order. However, I was met with great disappointment once diving into the movie. Although the creativity intrigued me, through the downfall of both the character style and the pacing, I lost interest quite quickly. My overall recommendation rating for this film is a solid 30%. The reason is that although some aspects were quite interesting, the movie presented no solid plotline, could not keep my attention, and was one of the most confusing films I had ever seen. I cannot judge the Sin City graphic novels because I have not read them, and sometimes the books are better than the films. However, considering this is only a film review, my opinion stands strong with not recommending this film to anybody interested in crime or action-related movies.

The movie Sin City is about four separate characters. This type of movie is called an anthology film. In the morning, he finds her dead next to him, so he sets on a journey to find her killer Cardinal Roark with her sister Wendy. Marv wants to punish him for taking away the one person that gave him attention other than his parole officer. 
What is interesting about the whole movie is that it was filmed in color but changed to black and white, this technique was used to portray the film's classic noir style. The filmmakers did this to make sure they kept with the original graphic novel's theme. In the movie, Goldie is all in color with dark red lips. At the time of the scene in the bed with Goldie, Marv talks about her beauty and how much of an angel she is. This is like what Scott McCloud talks about in Chapter 8 of Understanding Comics. He tells the readers about how the colors have an impact on the viewer's emotional ties to the text. We can take away from this scene that he obviously fell in love with her the first night he meets her. 
Another interesting thing I noticed while watching this film was the choice of colors they used for the actions. For example, in the next story after Marv's, when the one woman is killing all the men in the car and the blood is white, but when she cuts the man's head off in the street, the blood is red that comes across her face. I think it is also interesting how all the characters come together by the end of the story, we learn how the whole city is affected by all these criminal acts.

Unsettling neo-noir with a gripping, dark tale!

Directors Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller's neo-noir thriller Sin City (2005) adapts Miller's own graphic novel with a striking comic book style. It's impossible to describe just how striking Sin City is with its comic book and film noir aesthetic. Nothing looks like Sin City. I'm grateful for Rodriguez and Miller for directing their neo-noir masterpiece Sin City.

Frank Miller's writing is truly depressing, but so well written as he can describe a woman like a grim alleyway and it sounds romantic. Tonally, Sin City goes from violence so brutal that it's camp to unreal darkness with the most grim storylines blended with Frank Miller's bleak outlook on life. Sin City will disturb you with Frank Miller's brutal violence and shockingly dark narrative, while you'll be amazed by how he fits three main narratives together into one hard boiled film noir for modern audiences. Sin City is like watching separate tragedies colliding together in the most gloriously entertaining way. It's sorrowful and blunt with Frank Miller's wondrous way with words.

Bruce Willis really gave it his all with a subtle dramatic performance as the tough honest Detective John Hartigan. It's nice to see Willis really care about a role with all the nuance of his best acting style. Jessica Alba is sultry and sexy as the stripper Nancy Callahan, but it's her earnest love for Willis and inner pain that impresses more than her obvious beauty. Michael Madsen's quietly menacing bad cop Bob is the perfect antithesis for Bruce Willis' good cop. His cavalier attitude is quietly neat next to Willis' serious dramatic performance. Powers Boothe is as mean and vindictive as the sleazy, corrupt Senator Roark as you'd imagine. Nick Stahl is haunting as Roark Jr. and the Yellow Man. He's so eerie that I can never get his creepy face and performance out of my mind.

Clive Owen is so cool as the brutally vicious Dwight McCarthy. His every move feels lethal. Rosario Dawson has a confident and dangerous allure to her as Gail with a commanding romantic passion for Clive Owen that feels real. Alexis Bledel's piercing blue eyes astonish me with her sterling performance as the lovely prostitute Becky. She's really excellent in Sin City and makes me wonder how she didn't get cast in more films. I loved the icy coolness of Devon Aoki's hitwoman Miho as she doesn't waste a movement as the gorgeous lady of the night.

Furthermore, Benicio del Toro's forceful creep Jackie Boy is chilling from his compassionless deep voice to his sinister glare. He feels like Brittany Murphy's sweet waitress Shellie is in real danger. Murphy is so full of empathy for Shellie's poor life and luck with men as you see every bit of pain in Murphy's devastating eyes. She's breathtaking. Michael Clarke Duncan is pretty fun and intimidating as the police enforcer Manute.

Mickey Rourke is super rough and entertaining as the brute killer with a heart of gold called Marv. He's so in control of his every move and gravitas. Jaime King is drop dead gorgeous as both the sweet and mysterious Goldie and the viciously vengeful Wendy in Sin City. Her every glare and movement portray a stern fierceness that is hypnotizing throughout Rodriguez' film. Rutger Hauer's sleazy and revolting Cardinal Roark is intense and captivating. Carla Gugino is naturally beautiful as the parole officer Lucille with her nonchalant apathy to Marv's murders, while also giving a haunting and hysterical performance in the presence of Elijah Wood's stoic serial killer Kevin. Wood has never felt so evil with his swift movements and silent malice.

Josh Hartnett gets to open Sin City and close the film as his enigmatic hitman The Salesman. He's perfect with every choice word delivered with a cold deadpan of a man accustomed to murder. Frank Miller cameos as the priest who is not so holy. Nick Offerman is funny as one of the side henchmen.

Editor Robert Rodriguez manages to combine numerous plotlines into one massive neo-noir with a steady pace for 124 minutes. There's an uncut and extended edition I haven't seen, but I'm sure it adds some enthralling scenes, but the theatrical version is perfectly timed to just keep moving from kill to kill. Rodriguez also served as cinematographer. No one else could have filmed this movie like this and Sin City is as stylish as film gets. It visually looks like the old 1940's film noirs, while feeling distinctly modern in its sleekness. Everything pops from the splashes of red and yellow colors against the stark blacks and whites.

Christopher Stull, Steve Joyner, Jeanette Scott, and Emmanuel Shiu's art direction looks straight out of Frank Miller's graphic novel with the haunting cityscapes, empty rooftops, pouring rainfall, and gritty streets. Jeanette Scott, David Hack, and Rob Simons' set designs are cool with an ethereal aura to every place because it doesn't feel real despite looking all too hard-edged. Robert Rodriguez, Mauricio Baiocchi, and Keefe Boerner's visual effects blast gunshots and knives into people like it's nothing and I love how all out Sin City goes.

Composers Robert Rodriguez, John Debney, and Graeme Revell of The Crow fame wrote thrilling and moody music to fit Sin City's sleazy and forlorn vibe. Sure, Sin City is all naked women and rough men getting tortured and murdered, but it is inescapable. I find myself compelled to return to Frank Miller's world thanks to Rodriguez' passion in this project. It's very well made. Robert Rodriguez, Paula Fairfield, Craig Henighan, Sergio Reyes, and Tim Rakoczy all did the squishy, groaning, and bursting sound design that brings Sin City to life.

I appreciate Nina Proctor, Annette Hoffman, and Brenda J. Chambers' classically stylish noir outfits for the men with raunchy, horny outfits for the ladies. Sin City is certainly lustful, whether it's for nude women or the bloodlust only sated by killing men. Ermahn Ospina, Joe Rivera, and Scott Patton's make-up is incredible as they transform Bruce Willis into a scarred hard-boiled cop, Mickey Rourke into a thuggish monster, and Benicio Del Toro into a two-bit mug.

In all, Sin City will be better appreciated in time once viewers revisit Frank Miller's relentless world of bullets and babes within Rodriguez' stellar visual directing style. Miller is a visionary and Rodriguez is an auteur, so them directing Sin City together gave us a real balance of pragmatic realness and out of this world visceral violence.

Sin City is a deeply satisfying, woefully artistic, technologically revolutionary and well-written movie, adapted directly from some revolutionary graphic novels in what might be the most direct 1-to-1 Translation in the history of the medium.  This movie looks like an Ultra-HD Graphic Novel but in full motion, implementing artistic trappings impossible to achieve without lots of Post-Production trickery, something that all-too-often drags a movie down, but here elevates it up onto of the greatest Cinematic Artistic achievements of that decade, at times looking like a living painting.  Throw in outrageous amounts of brutal violence and more than a healthy dose of pitch-black humor, and you've got a genuine masterpiece of a movie.  If there was any real problem with the movie, it's really just that the Universe the story takes place in can't quite keep its own rules entirely straight - the Hero of one Story is put into a coma due to receiving a couple of gunshots, whereas the Hero of a different Story is able to not only take numerous gunshots AND direct impacts from vehicles, but he's also able to jump down large distances and highjack cars by smashing through the windshields, making these two characters feel like members of an entirely different species.  Also, the mid part of the movie does loose a bit of steam as it's the longest-winded in its storytelling, and plays out around the time that the audience has finally gotten over the brilliance of the spectacle.  But all 3 Stories are very well told, and the movie's thick atmosphere and deeply satisfying conclusions, make this an absolute must see, so long as you don't have problems with Hard-R Rated subject matter and content.

I have to commend Frank Miller and his co-directors for making such a bold visual choice with Sin City. It has a look that is one-of-a-kind and it truly embraces the dark art style of the graphic novels. I think the integration of the occasional color inside the black-and-white world is a dazzling way of focusing attention on certain things (even if it didn’t always make narrative sense to me why they chose those things to highlight.) There was a strange juxtaposition of retro cars with modern guns, and the language also seemed to be a mix of classic and modern. I’m not sure this made any sense, but it fit with the visual aesthetic they were creating for this world. I also appreciate the short story structure, because even if there is a story you don’t like, it doesn’t linger for long. I wish there was even more intertwining of the stories, aside from the occasional character popping up, because I’ve always been a fan of those kind of clever details linking a film together. It seemed like the only overriding theme that connected the entire film together was the miserable existence of every single person in this city, and the gruesome violence that ended most of their lives. What I didn’t like about Sin City was that it seemed to take everything to the extreme. It was all exaggerated too much, and that rarely worked for me. The stories are all dark and gritty and real, but then we have people shattering doors to splinters with one kick or jumping from 4th-story windows and landing smoothly on their feet. The two tones don’t work in the same world, and they lead me to chuckle instead of being engaged by the drama. The whole thing is also intended to have a strong neo-noir feeling to it, and that is most evident in the constant voiceover. There are times when that works to flesh out a story, but these aren’t complex plots that require that level of exposition. I also started to wonder if the voice coach for this film was just a bag of gravel the actors all had to gargle, because it seemed to be a competition to see who could be the deepest and most grumbly-voiced. You know it’s bad when I started to question if Benicio Del Toro was supposed to be the same character as Mickey Rourke, but they sounded so similar. I think Sin City was an ambitious idea, and I didn’t actively dislike it, but many of the choices they made didn’t work for me.

Wow, what a visually stunning spectacle. The amount of effort and intricacy that has gone into the style alone is quite awe-inspiring; with its ingenious use of colours to show characteristics or themes about characters adding a great deal to the excellent tone the film sets for itself. All the performances are wonderful too, and the lead trio of Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke and Clive Owen outdo themselves, and my expectations, in their respective segments. As this is a movie of three tales, it only makes sense to judge each one of them separately. 'That Yellow Bastard' was my favourite by quite some stretch. Not only was Willis excellent, but it has the most heartening and emotionally resonant story; and the way it both started and ended the movie was rather poignant also. Next, Rourke's 'The Hard Goodbye'. This was probably the most intriguing of the three stories, and I thoroughly enjoyed it; even though I think it went on a little too long. Finally, and the weakest of the three in my opinion - 'The Big Fat Kill'. Clive Owen is great, and a standout in the whole film, but this particular storyline just felt a little...empty. It had some great moments, but it dragged at times and by the end of it I was no more enlightened than I was at the start. All in all though, 'Sin City' is one helluva ambitious project, and both Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller must be commended for pulling off what on paper seemed almost an impossible task - creating, in effect, a live action animation.

In what is considered by many to be his magnum opus (an assertion of which I wholeheartedly agree), Robert Rodriguez has given us one of the best comic book movies to date. Never before have I witnessed such a beautifully rendered visual style on screen. The sharp black and white look with some striking colors throughout makes this a movie that, as clichéd as it sounds, feels like watching the pages of Frank Miller's graphic novel come to life. But even taking away that style, the movie still works for its extremely memorable characters and simple but engaging stories. Rodriguez has employed some of the best actors in the business with each bringing their A-game regardless of the size of their role. My personal favorite is Elijah Wood as the homicidal killer Kevin who manages to be extremely bone-chilling without saying a single word and with only about five minutes of screentime. Each story is well written (which of course owes much of that to Miller's original writing) and clear cut with solid characters and motivations. They work individually and as part of the larger narrative. In my humble opinion, That Yellow Bastard is the best (and most disturbing) and The Long Goodbye is the weakest (mainly for a few minor lingering plot points). But perhaps most importantly, Sin City is a film that radiates confidence. By confidence I mean that it's so sure of itself in its look, storytelling, performances, and enthusiasm that it gives the film that extra special element that is lacking in many other similar products. What could've been all style and no substance manages to be a happy medium of both. The end result is a special movie that it infinitely enticing. Yes, this is a cool movie and I say that as a fact.

"Sin City" is a collection of short stories set in the infamous Sin City, a city that lives up to it's named as it's filled with corruption, murders, prostitution, antiheroes and violence. 
Robert Rodriguez is a perfect match for Frank Miller´s over the top, dark and his tone that takes itself too seriously so "Sin City" looked like a promising experiment that ultimately succeeds but that doesn't mean it is a great film. Review In A Nutshell:

Sin City has blown people's minds during its release in 2005, and time has passed and many still hail it as one of the greatest films of its decade. I was certainly impressed by it, when I first saw it all those years ago; but time has passed and since then I have grown and my expectations for cinema as a whole has developed with a sense of maturity, therefore Frank Miller's Sin City has lost a bit of its impact on me during my recent viewing.

Sin City features four, loosely, interconnected stories that explores themes of corruption, murder, revenge, justice, and innocence. The story is certainly easy to follow and identifiable characters but beyond its surface, the film fails to deliver anything thought provoking with its themes. The film naturally draws its audience into its dark and terrifying world, but without any impact from the film's themes, the world and its plot simply felt hollow. It also does not help that the film features dialogue that sits in the borderline of being genuinely inspired and tiresome; with every amazing line, it counters with words that would make one sigh and roll their eyes as the statement being said was so obvious that I was distracted and taken aback from Frank Miller and Robert Rodriguez's world and characters.

The film fortunately was able to carry its weight through its visual and stylistic designs. The film does a wonderful job in recreating Frank Miller's black and white comic book, acting as a throwback to the elements of noir during the first half of the 20th century. There were actually a couple of moments in this film, where my mind paused for a second just to take in the gorgeous visuals. Though the spoken dialogue of the film left me disappointed, the internal monologue, however, was fantastic; it gave a three dimensional quality to the protagonists, aiding the audience in establishing these characters as heroes rather than anti-heroes.

Robert Rodriguez's ensemble cast was quite pleasing to watch, particularly Mickey Rourke. Rourke brought this hard grit to his role's personality, allowing his character to flourish in every frame he steps on. The rest of the cast may not reach the excellence that Rourke brought, but they definitely still showed a sense of commitment; cherishing the role that they were playing. If the cast brought a less than stellar performance, then it would have been difficult for the audience to be convinced of the city's intended darkness and sense of corruption.

I cannot see myself losing further admiration for Robert Rodriguez's Sin City as its visuals are simply too well executed for me to not appreciate; but due to its recent emerging flaws, I cannot glorify the film as I once did.

Frank Miller's comics/illustrated novels, have continually been dark, gritty and extremely unique in a visual sense. So imagine going back almost ten years ago, when it was announced that, one of his biggest selling books, Sin City, was not only going to be made, but he was going to co direct. At the time, it was something very little of us had seen before, much abused afterwards in creating other Frank Miller worlds, it boasted a mix of CGI and in camera effects, to give a living breathing comic strip. An experience that did not intrude and constantly distract but more envelop you as a viewer. This is down to two very important factors, its cast and Robert Rodriguez. Back when news of a Rodriguez film didnt fill your heart with dread, he was on his A game, providing comic book violence in a real world, it was almost like he was born to make this film. His credentials also managed to lock in quite a cast, which without this film would disintegrate very quickly. Sin City revolves around three of the Frank Miller novels, That Yellow Bastard, The Hard Goodbye and The Big Fat Kill. At the heart of each of these stories are three male protagonists, Hartigan, Marv and Dwight, three extremely dangerous, flawed but somehow caring citezans of Basin City, a city full of despair, crime, drugs, pedophiles and rapists. The film weaves the stories together seemlessly, offering up depravity upon depravity. Hartigan's story tells us of a retired cop, struggling to save a young girl from a pedophile son of a senator. Dwight follows a face changing criminal, who ends up in the middle of a war and has to side with the prostitutes of Basin City and finally Marv, who is framed for the murder of a high class call girl by two sickening cannibals. Its heavy stuff, thematically and visually. The cast are the important mould here, super stellar performances from Bruce Willis, Mickey Rourke, Rosario Dawson, Michael Clarke Duncan, Brittany Murphey, Benicio Del Toro, Elijah Wood and Nick Stahl, mixed with strong performances by Clive Owen, Devon Aioki, Josh Heartnett and Rutger Haur, leaving a couple of actors just dwindling in the dark really, for example Michael Madsen, who just doesnt comfortably suit into his small role, what so ever. Jessica Alba also has very little to do, being such a big character in the film, she ends up being just a damsel in distress. However as an ensemble they work magic, Narration from the three protagonists is perfect. Bruce Willis currently trying to prove to himself he isnt worthless as he tries to safe Jessica Alba from being raped is strong stuff, much like Marv's psychotic determination to bring the people who killed the love of his life to justice, even if he is imagening the whole thing. Clive Owen's narration is strong as well, its just he has little to play with, lucky for him Tarintino guest directs a scene with him and Del Toro that saves his entire sequence. Visually, if this were any other film it would be a horrendous and lazy cluster fuck of imagery but for the most part here, the blend between CGI and in camera works a joy, giving you a real sense of the world that its portraying. Awkward angles, brilliant tracking shots and some nice touches of colour here and there make the visuals stand out even more. There are moments when a characters lips will sheen violent red which clashes so harsh against the black and white it oozes sexy and noir. Its not all visually delightful though, the film has the odd moment where you wonder if they either ran out of time and just flung some parts in. A sequence where Marv tools up to go into battle just seems lazy and the final scene where a shamed prostitute meets her inevitable demise just reeks of last minute, which is a shame because these moments are really not needed in the film. The pacing is glorious also, each character may only have brief moments on screen but they light it up, meaning that every moment is an enjoyable romp. The edits are clean cut and on the ball, the score is pouncing and gets you right in the mood for the blood thirsty noir your watching. It is however not completely perfect. Some of the CGI, the cars mostley, have dated horribly, at points things feel slightly too rushed, i understand this is a two hour long film but a bit more time, could have gave actors such as Jessica Alba, just a bit more time to shine. Sin City Extended Edition (2005) - 8,5

4 little stories (one of them being a mini story) in the Neo-noir atmosphere of Sin City. I have mixed feelings about this movie. Not regarding the moral paradigma behind the stories of course, but about some cinematic aspects.. I really like the Neo-noir concept recreated here and there's a lot to apprecciate in this movie - the intelligent monologues of the protagonists, the noir atmosphere carved by the unique and interesting cinematography and colour treatment, the smart and mastertful way how the several plots develop, etc...

But... this is the sort of cinema that ideally transports the viewer into a different world, a fantasy, a dreamlike experience and this movie fails to do so (with me) on a consistent level and as a result it falls short of what I'd consider deserving of reverence. As I watched the movie I often found myself distracted and annoyed by an apparent amateurish nature and/or lack of skill in some technical aspects. I'm talking primarilly about some of the acting and sound work, things here could had been a lot more polished. For example, several characters didn't leave up to the demands of the movie, it seemed like some actors and actresses didn't give enough commitment or that they simply lacked the acting skills for their roles, they looked fake, forced, not authentic at all. The sound design and editing also lacked, in my opinion, as it often failed to immerse me into the Neo-noir atmosphere of the movie, I feel that this aspect was overlooked. Being a multi-plot movie, these shortcomings affected each story by different degrees and I felt that "The Big Fat Kill" was the worse case. It was by far the one I least cared for, pretty boring and little of interest, I often couldn't help but gaze away and sigh due to the lack of polishment in the aforementioned and several other aspects. The plot itself was also the least interestingly developed and the end was... well, uneventful and boring despite what it was... I just didn't feel like I was watching the same movie as the other stories at all... the character played by Benicio Del Toro was probably the only one remotely interesting to observe in "The Big Fat Kill".

"The Hard Goodbye" is a complete 180º turn though. I really liked this one, it was my favorite and if I had to score it alone, it'd be a solid 9. The main character is a brutal and amazeballs badass monster guy expertly played by Mickey Rourke, great work here! most of the acting in this story is pretty competent and the plot masterfully develops at the right pace and the sound design didn't let me down too much. This was definitely the immersive and dreamlike Neo-noir experience Sin City movie was supposed to be. The only oddity in my opinion was the character played by Elijah Wood... cmon man really?? so pathetic and amateurish looking!, it could had spoiled it all, but fortunately the overall work in "The Hard Goodbye" was solid and high quality so this nuissance didn't detract my enjoyment so much, but still it's the only stronger reason why I wouldn't give this single story a 10 if I had to.

On a general note special effects also looked excessively weird and unpolished a bit to often, it's just a small detail but nonetheless still has it's detracting influence on the screen.

I feel that the consistency of Sin City is damaged by the lack of consistency between the several stories that form the whole movie, but maybe it's unrealistic to expect the same quality standard throughout so many different plots and such big cast with a "mere" 40 million USD budget... Laying my thoughts on the available resources and the technical challenges present in the creation of this work I can see how this film may have been too ambitious for it's own good... I ansiously look forward to the next Sin City film and I hope it doesn't disapoint it's own aspirations.

EDIT: Just saw this movie again and I feel I didn't give it fair credit. I revise the rating to 8,5 and take back my negative words on the sound work. The sound work is actually remarkable, what the hell was in my head when I wrote the previous comments I don't know... I guess I didn't fully understand the movie at first... "The Yellow Bastard " story is the most polished work, it's beautiful, but my favourite is still "The Hard Goodbye". Unfortunately my view towards "The Big Fat Kill" haven't changed much, actually most of the things that I negatively criticise are confined to this part. I wish they hadn't included this story in the film because it really detracts from the overall positive impression I have of the movie. This would easily become one of my favorite films of all time if they hadn't screw it up with "The Big Fat Kill". It's still a beautiful movie!
